title: Question 39

children: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-month history of a painless lesion on his left shoulder that has been increasing in size and is now 2 cm in diameter. Medical history is unremarkable.

). In general, the ABCDE identifying characteristics (Asymmetry, irregular Border, multiple Colors, Diameter >6 mm, and Evolution or change over time) can help diagnose melanoma. However, nodular melanomas do not always fulfill the ABCDE diagnostic criteria. As seen in this patient, nodular melanomas may be uniform in color and have regular, symmetric borders, making them difficult to diagnose until a later stage. Most nodular melanomas are smooth, but others are eroded and have a particularly poor prognosis. Nodular melanomas grow rapidly (fulfilling the Evolution diagnostic criterion), particularly vertical growth, and are more aggressive than other subtypes. Because of the increased thickness of the melanoma at diagnosis and aggressive behavior, prompt identification, biopsy, and treatment are imperative. All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied. The preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 3-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and prevent sampling error.

After its rapid growth, some keratoacanthomas tend to involute in 6 months. Because keratoacanthomas are difficult to differentiate from squamous cell carcinoma, they are often treated with surgical excision. The lack of a keratin-filled center and uniform black pigmentation of this patient's skin lesion differentiates it from a keratoacanthoma.
